IT runs Nagios in house for round-the-clock monitoring of general hosts 
and services. A number of our development groups build bioinformatics 
databases, API's to access them, and clients that use the data for 
visualization and automated data mining. Much of this happens in Java. 
So, given that a number of our data access API's are in Java, it seems 
natural to write tests in JUnit. My group would like to have some 
services periodically checked for up status, performance profiling and 
so on, hence Nagios.

Anyway, I just ended up writing a little perl script that simple runs a 
given junit test, parses the junits output and prints the test summaries 
at specified verbosity levels, in (loose) compliance with the Nagios 
plugin API. Seems crude, but we'll see how it goes...

Rod

Jason Rogers wrote:

>On Mon, 20 Sep 2004 13:18:02 -0400, Rod Gonzaga <rgonzaga@...>  
>wrote:
>
>  
>
>>I am interested in running automatic periodic tests using JUnit and
>>Nagios. Has anyone had experience with this? Perhaps a Nagios plugin
>>already exists to integrate JUnit testing?
>>    
>>
>
>I've never heard of one existing.
>
>It isn't clear to me what you want to do here.  Do you want a command in  
>your Nagios config that will run a certain set of tests?  If so, what is  
>the perceived benefit?
>
>I really am curious about this, I am not trying to poke holes.  I never  
>considered doing something like this and would like to know what your  
>UseCase is.
>
>Thanks.
>
>  
>
